results.title: The Lau of Malaita
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International and Leslie Woodhead
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Disappearing world”.
Episode 4 of this five part series looks at the story of the people of the Lau Lagoon. 600 years ago in the Solomon Islands, the Lau people abandoned the hills of Malaita to start a new life, incredibly, by constructing small coral islands in the idyllic Pacific lagoon below. Today most of the 60 island communities in the Lau Lagoon have come under Christian missionary influence which has transformed their entire system of beliefs and values and replaced the original “life of custom”. This program shows the villagers taking positive steps to revive their dying traditions.

results.title: The Late Show: The Olden days
results.creator_credit: D Generation, ABC-TV (Australia) and Mark Gibson
results.brief_description: In the hands of the D-Generation the original ABC series of ‘Rush’ becomes a steamy tale of hope, betrayal and false moustaches set against the rarely-convincing backdrop of the Victorian ‘mudfields’. Also features a featurette at the end of “Olden Days” which is a tribute to that great Australian auteur Warren Perso (starring Tony Martin and Judith Lucy).

results.title: The Late Show presents: 'The devil at your heels'
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, BBC, Robert Fortier, Adam Symansky and Bill Brand
results.brief_description: This documentary on Canadian stuntman Ken Carter and his obsession with jumping a car over the St Lawrence Seaway - a distance of 1 mile - is presented by Rob Sitch, Santo Cilauro and Aaron Beaucaire, “Late Show” stalwarts and keen amateur stuntmen. Originally shot by reporters form the National Film Board of Canada, the film spans the five years it took to achieve this absurd feat. At 16 Ken Carter joined Joey Chitwood’s “Congress of Canadian Daredevils”. At 17, he was with “The International Hell Drivers”. Twenty years and fifty broken bones later, he decides his one last stunt will be to jump a rocket car from Canada to the USA over the St Lawrence Seaway.

results.title: The Late Show : Bargearse
results.creator_credit: D-Generation, ABC-TV (Australia), Crawfords and Mark Gibson
results.brief_description: By re-voicing the classic 1976 Crawford’s police drama ‘Bluey’, the D-Generation have created an entirely new story which is at once a subtle rumination on the nature of existence, and a thinly-veiled excuse for some really good fart jokes. It should be pointed out that this is not for the faint-hearted or those who may have just eaten.

results.title: The Late show
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Robert Altman and Robert Benton
results.brief_description: Ira Wells (Art Carney) is an ageing private eye trying to solve the murder of his ex-partner (Howard Duff), “helped” by Margo (Lily Tomlin), a flaky, aimless young woman. The chemistry between Carney and Tomlin is perfect and echoes of Chandler and Hammett resound in Benton’s complex but likeable script. This quietly authoritative show-stopper is a marvellous comment on classics like “The Maltese Falcon” and “The Big Sleep”, while at the same time taking its place beside them as a superior example of the genre. Also starring Bill Macy and Eugene Roche. Co-starring Joanna Cassidy, John Considine, Ruth Nelson, Howard Duff and John Davey.

results.title: The Last wild river
results.brief_description: Covers an expedition in 1977 by four people including Bob Brown and Peter Thompson, down the wild Franklin River in Western Tasmania using rubber rafts. Shows much of the aesthetic and recreational value of this wilderness environment and introduces the conservation dispute focused on this area.

results.title: The Last whalers
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation, William Neufeld and Julien Bryan
results.brief_description: A study of simple European life that focuses on a group of whalers and on the customs and traditions of the Pico Island villages. Filmed on Pico Island, The Azores (Portugal).

results.title: The Last Wave [DVD] (A)
results.creator_credit: Ayer Productions, Hal McElroy, James McElroy and Peter Weir
results.brief_description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending Aborigines against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. Step by step a series of apparently random occurences assume a disturbing pattern. The city becomes a facade for a place of ancient ritual. Cast includes Richard Chamberlain and David Gulpilil and features photography by Russell Boyd. Features a digitally restored soundtrack.

results.title: The Last warriors
results.creator_credit: Transmedia Productions, Michael Willesee Jnr and Ben Ulm
results.brief_description: Television documentary series in five episodes presented and narrated by Mike Willesee looking at the traditional lifestyles and rituals of various African tribes. Ep. 1 focuses on the Hamar and Karo tribes. Ep. 2 follows the Wodaabe and Tureg people, nomadic tribes of the Sahara Desert. In Ep. 3 men from the Mursi tribe prepare for a traditional fighting ritual. Ep. 4 looks at a traditional tribal marriage. Dinka men prepare for an eating contest in Ep. 5. Ep. 6 is a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the series.

results.title: The Last waltz [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Last Waltz Productions, Robbie Robertson and Martin Scorsese
results.brief_description: The Band, the American 1970s rock outfit, were together fifteen years. “The Last waltz” is their farewell concert, staged in 1976 and filmed by Martin Scorsese, that featured a plethora of rock stars including Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell, Neil Diamond, Van Morrison, Emmylou Harris, Ringo Starr, Neil Young, Eric Clapton, Muddy Waters, The Staples, Dr. John, Ronnie Hawkins, Paul Butterfield, Ron Wood and The Band themselves. As well as filming the occasion, Scorsese also interviewed The Band about their lifestyles, the rigours of touring and their reasons for discontinuing. His footage, which includes some frank and very personal moments, acts as a bittersweet look at an era that was just beginning to fade. Still considered, in terms of quality, one of the best rock concerts ever filmed.
